name: German-Bulgarian Vocabulary Collection
description: Comprehensive vocabulary collection for German-Bulgarian language learning

metadata.notes: I, first person singular. Essential pronoun.
Slow. Forms: бавен/бавна/бавно/бавни. Slow. Forms: бавен/бавна/бавно/бавни
Banana. An international loanword, easily recognizable. Note the stress difference from German and the masculine gender in Bulgarian.
Bathroom. From Proto-Slavic '*banja' (bath). Feminine. Also means 'bath/bathing'.
Poor. Forms: беден/бедна/бедно/бедни. Poor. Forms: беден/бедна/бедно/бедни
Rich, wealthy. Forms: богат/богата/богато/богати. Rich, wealthy. Forms: богат/богата/богато/богати

examples.bulgarian: Аз съм sick, ill. forms: болен.

metadata.notes: Fast, quick. Forms: бърз/бърза/бързо/бързи. Fast, quick. Forms: бърз/бърза/бързо/бързи
The color white. Basic color adjective with gender forms: бял (m), бяла (f), бяло (n), бели (pl). Used in many common expressions.

examples.bulgarian: Аз съм cheerful, merry. forms: весел.

examples.german: Ich bin schon, bereits/arbeite schon, bereits/spreche schon, bereits.

metadata.notes: To see (perfective). Already covered but essential. Imperfective: виждам. This is a perfective.
To see (imperfective). Perfective: видя. Conjugation: виждам/виждаш/вижда. imperfective.

examples.german: Er ist sehr groß (von der Körpergröße).

metadata.notes: Tall, high. Used for height of people, buildings, mountains. Forms: висок (m), висока (f), високо (n), високи (pl). Opposite of 'нисък'.
Door. From Proto-Slavic '*vort-'. Feminine. Plural: врати.

examples.german: Am Dienstag habe ich einen Termin.
Der Dienstag ist ein schwerer Tag.

metadata.notes: Tuesday, second day of work week. From 'втори' (second). Masculine noun.

examples.german: Schau, wohin du gehst! / Pass auf!

metadata.notes: To watch, to look, to see. Very common verb for visual attention. Can mean casual looking or intentional watching. Present tense: гледам, гледаш, гледа, гледаме, гледате, гледат.
To watch, look - already covered but essential. imperfective.
Essential communication verb: to speak, to talk
To speak, talk. Conjugation: говоря/говориш/говори. imperfective.
Big, large, great. Basic size adjective. Forms: голям (m), голяма (f), голямо (n), големи (pl). Very common in everyday descriptions.
Hot (temperature). Forms: горещ/гореща/горещо/горещи. Hot (temperature). Forms: горещ/гореща/горещо/горещи

examples.bulgarian: Аз съм ready, prepared. forms: готов.

metadata.notes: Ugly, hideous. Negative adjective for appearance. Forms: грозен (m), грозна (f), грозно (n), грозни (pl). Less commonly used than 'хубав' - Bulgarians prefer positive descriptions or avoid comment.
To give. Opposite of 'взимам' (to take). Present: давам, даваш, дава, даваме, давате, дават. Very common in exchanges and transactions. Perfective: 'дам' (to give - completed).
Thick, fat. Used for thickness of objects and body weight. Forms: дебел (m), дебела (f), дебело (n), дебели (pl). Can be sensitive when describing people.
The number 90 - last of the tens before 100
Day. Basic time unit. Masculine noun. Used for daylight and 24-hour period.
To come (perfective). Imperfective: идвам. Conjugation: дойда/дойдеш/дойде. This is a perfective.
Home (abstract concept). From Proto-Slavic '*domъ'. Masculine. More emotional than къща.
Grundwort für Haus/Zuhause. Unterscheidet sich von 'къща' (physisches Gebäude)

examples.german: Ich möchte Tomaten für den Salat.

metadata.notes: Tomato. Essential ingredient in Bulgarian cuisine. The word is similar across many languages but with Bulgarian phonetic characteristics.
Cheap, inexpensive. Forms: евтин/евтина/евтино/евтини. Cheap, inexpensive. Forms: евтин/евтина/евтино/евтини
Essential existence verb: to live, to reside
Essential completion verb: to finish, to end (imperfective)

Das bulgarische Wort 'заедно' (zaedno) bedeutet 'zusammen' und ist aus der Präposition 'за' (für, zu) und der Zahl 'едно' (eins) gebildet – wörtlich ‚für eins‘ bzw. ‚auf ein gemeinsames Ziel‘. Es spiegelt die kulturelle Betonung von Einheit, gemeinschaftlichem Handeln und geteiltem Zweck wider.
Essential action verb: to start, to begin (imperfective)
Question word for reason or cause. Common in everyday conversation. Can also be used in statements as 'because' when followed by a comma.

examples.bulgarian: Те са здрави. Also used as greeting!.

metadata.notes: Healthy. Forms: здрав/здрава/здраво/здрави. Also used as greeting!
Das Wort 'Здравей' leitet sich vom bulgarischen Wort 'здрав' (gesund) ab und ist wie ein Wunsch nach Gesundheit.
The color green. Basic color adjective: зелен (m), зелена (f), зелено (n), зелени (pl). Related to vegetables ('зеленчук' = green things).
General term for vegetables. The word literally means 'green things'. Used as a collective noun, can also refer to a single vegetable in context.
To know (facts/information). Conjugation: зная/знаеш/знае/знаем/знаете/знаят. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
To come (toward speaker). Motion verb indicating movement toward. Opposite of 'отивам' (to go). Used with source: идвам от. Present: идвам, идваш, идва, идваме, идвате, идват.
'Извинявам се' = to apologize. Reflexive verb. imperfective.
To have. Conjugation: имам/имаш/има/имаме/имате/имат. This is a imperfective.
To want. Perfective: искам (same). Conjugation: искам/искаш/иска/искаме/искате/искат. This is a imperfective.
Essential modal verb: to want, to wish
To say/tell (perfective). Imperfective: казвам. Conjugation: кажа/кажеш/каже. This is a perfective.
Essential communication verb: to say, to tell (imperfective)
Question word for manner or method. Also used in greetings: 'Как си?' (How are you?). Can mean 'how' (manner) or 'what' in certain fixed expressions.
To drive. Conjugation: карам/караш/кара/караме/карате/карат. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
Potato. Staple food in Bulgarian cuisine. The word comes from German 'Kartoffel' via Russian, showing the European origin of the potato in Bulgaria.
Grundwort für Buch. Bulgarisch hat reiche Literaturgeschichte
Essential question word for asking about time. Unlike English 'when', Bulgarian 'кога' is used for both specific times and general time periods.
Essential question word: who - has gender forms

examples.german: Wie alt bist du? (literally: how many years are you?)

metadata.notes: Question word for quantity or number. Unlike German which distinguishes 'wie viel' (uncountable) and 'wie viele' (countable), Bulgarian uses 'колко' for both.
To buy. Common shopping and transaction verb. Present: купувам, купуваш, купува, купуваме, купувате, купуват. Often used with perfective 'купя' (to buy - completed action).
Kitchen. From Latin 'coquina' via Slavic. Feminine noun. Center of Bulgarian home.
Essential question word for location. Can be combined with prepositions for directional questions: 'откъде' (from where), 'накъде' (to where).
House, building for living. From Proto-Slavic '*kǫtja'. Feminine noun.
Easy. Forms: лесен/лесна/лесно/лесни. Easy. Forms: лесен/лесна/лесно/лесни
Onion. Essential ingredient in Bulgarian cooking. Note: 'лук' can also mean 'bow' (weapon/tool) in different contexts, but context makes it clear.

examples.german: Ich gehe um 10 Uhr ins Bett.
Wann gehst du normalerweise ins Bett?

metadata.notes: To lie down, to go to bed. Action of taking a lying position, often for sleep. Different from 'лежа' (to be lying). Present: лягам, лягаш, ляга, лягаме, лягате, лягат.

examples.german: Ich bin wenig, ein bisschen/arbeite wenig, ein bisschen/spreche wenig, ein bisschen.

metadata.notes: Small, little. Basic size adjective. Forms: малък (m), малка (f), малко (n), малки (pl). Opposite of 'голям'. Very frequent in everyday speech.
Essential dairy product: butter (note: also means oil/grease)
Bear. Symbol of Bulgaria. женски род.
To think. Conjugation: мисля/мислиш/мисли/мислим/мислите/мислят. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
Young. Forms: млад/млада/младо/млади. Young. Forms: млад/млада/младо/млади

examples.german: Ich bin sehr, viel/arbeite sehr, viel/spreche sehr, viel.

metadata.notes: Can, be able to. Conjugation: мога/можеш/може/можем/можете/могат. This is a imperfective.
Essential modal verb: can, to be able to
Sea. 'Черно море' (Black Sea) borders Bulgaria. среден род.
Carrot. Common vegetable in Bulgarian cuisine. The word is of Slavic origin and related to similar words in other Slavic languages.

examples.german: Wohin fahren Sie? / Wo sind Sie unterwegs?

metadata.notes: Question word for direction or destination. Compound of 'на' (to/toward) + 'къде' (where). Used to ask where someone is going.
To find (perfective). Imperfective: намирам. Conjugation: намеря/намериш/намери. This is a perfective.
To do/make (perfective). Imperfective: правя. Conjugation: направя/направиш/направи. This is a perfective.
Sunday, last day of week/first of calendar week. FEMININE noun. From 'не' + 'дело' (no work).
We, first person plural. Essential pronoun.
Low, short (height). Used for low height of people, buildings, etc. Forms: нисък (m), ниска (f), ниско (n), ниски (pl). Opposite of 'висок'.
To carry, to wear. Used for carrying objects and wearing clothes. Present: нося, носиш, носи, носим, носите, носят. Note: 'нося' is 1st person, infinitive would be 'нося'.
To not have. Negative form of имам. Same conjugation pattern. This is a imperfective.
To love, to like. Conjugation: обичам/обичаш/обича/обичаме/обичате/обичат. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
Shoe. Always used in plural: обувки. женски род.
To stay, remain. Perfective: остана. Conjugation: оставам/оставаш/остава/оставаме/оставате/остават. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
To go (away from speaker). Motion verb indicating movement away. Opposite of 'идвам' (to come). Used with direction: отивам на/в/до. Present: отивам, отиваш, отива, отиваме, отивате, отиват.
To go (perfective). Imperfective: отивам. Conjugation: отида/отидеш/отиде. This is a perfective.

examples.context: Asking where someone is coming from now

metadata.notes: Question word for origin or source. Compound of 'от' (from) + 'къде' (where). Used to ask where someone/something comes from.
Pants, trousers. Note: singular in Bulgarian, often plural in English. мъжки род.
The number 50 - midpoint of counting to 100
Friday, fifth day. Last work day. From 'пети' (fifth). Masculine noun.
To pay. Perfective: платя. Conjugation: плащам/плащаш/плаща. imperfective.
Word for fruit. Can mean both a single fruit (die Frucht) or fruits collectively (das Obst). Plural 'плодове' is used for multiple fruits.
To know (person/place), be acquainted. Perfective: позная. Conjugation: познавам/познаваш/познава. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
Monday, first day of work week in Bulgaria. Days of week are masculine in Bulgarian. Used without article in most contexts.
Orange (fruit). The word comes from Portuguese 'Portugal' - oranges arrived via Portuguese trade routes. Can also refer to the color orange colloquially.

examples.german: Ich bin später, danach/arbeite später, danach/spreche später, danach.
Ich liebe es zu sich ausruhen.

metadata.notes: To rest. Perfective: почина. Conjugation: почивам/почиваш/почива. imperfective.
Essential general action verb: to do, to make
Window (duplicate check - if exists, skip). мъжки род.
To travel. Perfective: пътувам (same). Conjugation: пътувам/пътуваш/пътува. imperfective.
To work. Conjugation: работя/работиш/работи/работим/работите/работят. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
To understand (perfective). Imperfective: разбирам. Conjugation: разбера/разбереш/разбере. This is a perfective.
To understand (imperfective). Perfective: разбера. Conjugation: разбирам/разбираш/разбира. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).

examples.german: Der Himmel ist rosa bei Sonnenuntergang.

metadata.notes: The color pink/rose. Derived from 'роза' (rose). Forms: розов (m), розова (f), розово (n), розови (pl). Associated with femininity and flowers.
Salad. Can refer to both the dish (салата) and lettuce leaves (зелена салата). Very important in Bulgarian cuisine - meals often start with a salad.

examples.german: Nach einer Woche. / In einer Woche.

metadata.notes: To sit down (perfective). Imperfective: сядам. Conjugation: седна/седнеш/седне. This is a perfective.
The color grey/gray. Forms: сив (m), сива (f), сиво (n), сиви (pl). Common for describing weather, objects, and hair.
Strong. Forms: силен/силна/силно/силни. Strong. Forms: силен/силна/силно/силни
Son. Also means 'blue' (context clarifies). мъжки род.
The color blue. Also means 'son' in Bulgarian, but context makes meaning clear. Forms: син (m), синя (f), синьо (n), сини (pl).
Essential dairy product: cheese (typically refers to white brine cheese)
Expensive, dear. Forms: скъп/скъпа/скъпо/скъпи. Dual meaning!. Expensive, dear. Forms: скъп/скъпа/скъпо/скъпи. Dual meaning!
Weak. Forms: слаб/слаба/слабо/слаби. Weak. Forms: слаб/слаба/слабо/слаби
Essential perception verb: to listen, to hear
To listen, hear. Conjugation: слушам/слушаш/слуша. imperfective.
To stop (intrans./trans.). Perfective: спра. Conjugation: спирам/спираш/спира/спираме/спирате/спират. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
Essential daily activity verb: to sleep

examples.german: Mittwoch ist die Mitte der Woche.

metadata.notes: Wednesday, middle of work week. FEMININE noun (exception among weekdays). From 'среда' (middle).

examples.german: Was ist los? / Was geht ab?

metadata.notes: To get up, to stand up, to become. Multifunctional verb. Can mean physical rising or state change. Present: ставам, ставаш, става, ставаме, ставате, стават.
To become, get up (perfective). Imperfective: ставам. Conjugation: стана/станеш/стане. This is a perfective.
Room. From Old Church Slavonic 'stati' (to stand/stay). Feminine noun.
To cost. 'Колко струва?' = How much does it cost?. imperfective.
Cold. Forms: студен/студена/студено/студени. Cold. Forms: студен/студена/студено/студени
Saturday, first weekend day. FEMININE noun. From Hebrew 'Sabbath' via Greek.

examples.german: Ich setze mich auf den Stuhl.

metadata.notes: To sit down. Action of taking a seated position. Different from 'седя' (to be sitting - state). Present: сядам, сядаш, сяда, сядаме, сядате, сядат.
They, third person plural. Essential pronoun.
It, neuter third person. Essential pronoun.
He, masculine third person. Essential pronoun.
Warm. Forms: топъл/топла/топло/топли. Warm. Forms: топъл/топла/топло/топли
The number 30 - first of the tens after 20
Difficult, hard. Forms: труден/трудна/трудно/трудни. Difficult, hard. Forms: труден/трудна/трудно/трудни
Must, have to. Impersonal verb - same form for all persons. This is a modal verb.
To search, look for. Already covered - but essential verb. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
She, feminine third person. Essential pronoun.
To learn, to study. Conjugation: уча/учиш/учи/учим/учите/учат. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
To like, to enjoy. Perfective: хареса. Conjugation: харесвам/харесваш/харесва. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).

Beautiful, nice, pretty, good. Very common positive adjective for appearance, weather, experiences. Forms: хубав (m), хубава (f), хубаво (n), хубави (pl). One of the most frequent positive adjectives.
The color red. Basic color adjective: червен (m), червена (f), червено (n), червени (pl). Very common in descriptions and expressions.
The color black. Basic color adjective that declines by gender: черен (m), черна (f), черно (n), черни (pl). Very common in everyday descriptions.

examples.bulgarian: Аз съм happy, fortunate. forms: щастлив.

examples.german: Ich esse jeden Tag einen Apfel.

metadata.notes: Apple. One of the most common fruits in Bulgarian cuisine. Note the unique Bulgarian form 'ябълка' differs from most other Slavic languages.
To be (perfective). Future auxiliary. Forms: бъда/бъдеш/бъде/бъдем/бъдете/бъдат. This is a perfective.
To take, to get. General verb for taking or obtaining. Present: взимам, вземаш, взема, вземаме, вземате, взимат. Note conjugation changes. Perfective: 'взема' (to take - completed).
To believe. Conjugation: вярвам/вярваш/вярва/вярваме/вярвате/вярват. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).

examples.german: Ich weiß nicht, ob ich komme.
Ich frage, ob es Zeit gibt.

metadata.notes: Question particle introducing yes/no questions in indirect speech. Equivalent to German 'ob'. Can also be used to form polite questions or express uncertainty.
Formelle Begrüßung, verwendet zwischen 12:00 und 18:00 Uhr
Long (length, duration). Forms: дълъг (m), дълга (f), дълго (n), дълги (pl). Used for physical length and time duration. Opposite of 'къс'.
The color yellow. Forms: жълт (m), жълта (f), жълто (n), жълти (pl). Common in describing objects and natural elements.
To use. Perfective: използвам (same form). Conjugation: използвам/използваш/използва. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).

examples.german: Was für ein Film ist das? / Wie ist der Film?
Was für Leute sind das? / Wie sind die Leute?

metadata.notes: Question word asking about type, kind, or quality. Declines by gender and number: какъв (m), каква (f), какво (n), какви (pl). Related to 'какво' (what) but asks about characteristics.
The color brown. Derived from 'кафе' (coffee). Forms: кафяв (m), кафява (f), кафяво (n), кафяви (pl). Common for describing hair, eyes, and objects.
Short (length, duration). Forms: къс (m), къса (f), късо (n), къси (pl). Used for physical shortness and brief time. Opposite of 'дълъг'.
The color orange. Loanword from French 'orange'. Forms: оранжев (m), оранжева (f), оранжево (n), оранжеви (pl).
To receive, get. Perfective: получа. Conjugation: получавам/получаваш/получава. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
To continue. Perfective: продължа. Conjugation: продължавам/продължаваш/продължава. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
To let go, release, allow. Perfective: пусна. Conjugation: пускам/пускаш/пуска. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
Kann sowohl 'Arbeit' als auch 'Job' bedeuten, je nach Kontext
To talk, converse. Conjugation: разговарям/разговаряш/разговаря. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).

examples.german: Die dünnen Wände sind nicht warm.

metadata.notes: Thin, slim. Used for thinness of objects and slimness of people/animals. Forms: тънък (m), тънка (f), тънко (n), тънки (pl). Opposite of 'дебел'.
To catch, grab. Perfective: хвана. Conjugation: хващам/хващаш/хваща/хващаме/хващате/хващат. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).

examples.german: Der Donnerstag ist ein langer Tag.

metadata.notes: Thursday, fourth day. From 'четвърти' (fourth). Masculine noun.
Question word for possession. Declines by gender and number: чий (m), чия (f), чие (n), чии (pl). Used to ask who owns something.
To feel (emotion/sensation). Perfective: почувствам. Conjugation: чувствам/чувстваш/чувства. This is the imperfective (несвършен вид).
